books.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 1

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 1:1
verses.text: Extant Fragments of the Chronography: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 1:2
verses.text: The Egyptians, indeed, with their boastful notions of their own antiquity, have put forth a sort of account of it by the hand of their astrologers in cycles and myriads of years; which some of those who have had the repute of studying such subjects profoundly have in a summary way called lunar years; and inclining no less than others to the mythical, they think they fall in with the eight or nine thousands of years which the Egyptian priests in Plato falsely reckon up to Solon.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 1:3
verses.text: (And after some other matter:)  For why should I speak of the three myriad years of the Phoenicians, or of the follies of the Chaldeans, their forty-eight myriads? For the Jews, deriving their origin from them as descendants of Abraham, having been taught a modest mind, and one such as becomes men, together with the truth by the spirit of Moses, have handed down to us, by their extant Hebrew histories, the number of  years as the period up to the advent of the Word of salvation, that was announced to the world in the time of the sway of the Caesars.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 2

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 2:1
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 2:2
verses.text: When men multiplied on the earth, the angels of heaven came together with the daughters of men.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 2:3
verses.text: In some copies I found "the sons of God".

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 2:4
verses.text: What is meant by the Spirit, in my opinion, is that the descendants of Seth are called the sons of God on account of the righteous men and patriarchs who have sprung from him, even down to the Saviour Himself; but that the descendants of Cain are named the seed of men, as having nothing divine in them, on account of the wickedness of their race and the inequality of their nature, being a mixed people, and having stirred the indignation of God.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 2:5
verses.text: But if it is thought that these refer to angels, we must take them to be those who deal with magic and jugglery, who taught the women the motions of the stars and the knowledge of things celestial, by whose power they conceived the giants as their children, by whom wickedness came to its height on the earth, until God decreed that the whole race of the living should perish in their impiety by the deluge.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:1
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:2
verses.text: Adam, when  years old, begets Seth; and after living other  years he died, that is, a second death.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:3
verses.text: Seth, when  years old, begot Enos; from Adam therefore to the birth of Enos there are  years in all.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:4
verses.text: Enos, when  years old, begets Cainan.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:5
verses.text: Cainan again, when  years old, begets Malaleel;  And Malaleel, when  years old; begets Jared;  And Jared, when  years old, begets Enoch;  And Enoch, when  years old, begets Mathusala; and having pleased God, after a life of other  years, he was not found.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:6
verses.text: Mathusala, when  years old, begot Lamech.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 3:7
verses.text: Lamech, when  years old, begets Noe.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:1
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:2
verses.text: On the Deluge.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:3
verses.text: God decreed to destroy the whole race of the living by a flood, having threatened that men should not survive beyond  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:4
verses.text: Nor let it be deemed a matter of difficulty, because some lived afterwards a longer period than that.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:5
verses.text: For the space of time meant was  years up to the flood in the case of the sinners of that time; for they were  years old.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:6
verses.text: God instructed Noe, who pleased him on account of his righteousness, to prepare an ark; and when it was finished, there entered it Noe himself and his sons, his wife and his daughters-in-law, and firstlings of every living creature, with a view to the duration of the race.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:7
verses.text: And Noe was  years old when the flood came on.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:8
verses.text: And when the water abated, the ark settled on the mountains of Ararat, which we know to be in Parthia; but some say that they are at Celaenae of Phrygia, and I have seen both places.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:9
verses.text: And the flood prevailed for a year, and then the earth became dry.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:10
verses.text: And they came out of the ark in pairs, as may be found, and not in the manner in which they had entered, viz.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:11
verses.text: , distinguished according to their species, and were blessed by God.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 4:12
verses.text: And each of these things indicates something useful to us.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 5

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 5:1
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 5:2
verses.text: Noe was  years old when the flood came on.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 5:3
verses.text: From Adam, therefore, to Noe and the flood, are  years.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6:1
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6:2
verses.text: And after the flood, Sem begot Arphaxad.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6:3
verses.text: Arphaxad, when  years old, begets Sala in the year.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6:4
verses.text: Sala, when  years old, begets Heber in the year.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6:5
verses.text: Heber, when  years old, begets Phalec in the year , so called because the earth was divided in his days.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 6:6
verses.text: Phalec, when  years old, begot Ragan, and after living other  years died.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 7

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 7:1
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 7:2
verses.text: In the year of the world , Abraham entered the promised land of Canaan.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8:1
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8:2
verses.text: Of Abraham.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8:3
verses.text: From this rises the appellation of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8:4
verses.text: For the word Hebrews is interpreted to mean those who migrate across, viz.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8:5
verses.text: , who crossed the Euphrates with Abraham; and it is not derived, as some think, from the fore-mentioned Heber.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 8:6
verses.text: From the flood and Noe, therefore, to Abraham's entrance into the promised land, there are in all  years; and from Adam, in  generations  years.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:1
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:2
verses.text: Of Abraham and Lot.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:3
verses.text: When a famine pressed the land of Canaan, Abraham came down to Egypt; and fearing lest he should be put out of the way on account of the beauty of his wife, he pretended that he was her brother.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:4
verses.text: But Pharaoh took her to himself when she was commended to him; for this is the name the Egyptians give their kings.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:5
verses.text: And he was punished by God; and Abraham, along with all pertaining to him, was dismissed enriched.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:6
verses.text: In Canaan, Abraham's shepherds and Lot's contended with each other; and with mutual consent they separated, Lot choosing to dwell in Sodom on account of the fertility and beauty of the land, which had five cities, Sodom, Gomorrah, Adama, Seboim, Segor, and as many kings.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:7
verses.text: On these their neighbours the four Syrian kings made war, whose leader was Chodollogomor king of aelam.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:8
verses.text: And they met by the Salt Sea, which is now called the Dead Sea.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:9
verses.text: In it I have seen very many wonderful things.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:10
verses.text: For that water sustains no living thing, and dead bodies are carried beneath its depths, while the living do not readily even dip under it.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:11
verses.text: Lighted torches are borne upon it, but when extinguished they sink.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:12
verses.text: And there are the springs of bitumen; and it yields alum and salt a little different from the common kinds, for they are pungent and transparent.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:13
verses.text: And wherever fruit is found about it, it is found full of a thick, foul smoke.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:14
verses.text: And the water acts as a cure to those who use it, and it is drained in a manner contrary to any other water.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:15
verses.text: And if it had not the river Jordan feeding it like a shell, and to a great extent withstanding its tendency, it would have failed more rapidly than appears.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 9:16
verses.text: There is also by it a great quantity of the balsam plant; but it is supposed to have been destroyed by God on account of the impiety of the neighbouring people.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:1
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:2
verses.text: Of the Patriarch Jacob.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:3
verses.text: The shepherd's tent belonging to Jacob, which was preserved at Edessa to the time of Antonine Emperor of the Romans, was destroyed by a thunderbolt.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:4
verses.text: Jacob, being displeased at what had been done by Symeon and Levi at Shecem against the people of the country, on account of the violation of their sister, buried at Shecem the gods which he had with him near a rock under the wonderful terebinth, which up to this day is reverenced by the neighbouring people in honour of the patriarchs, and removed thence to Bethel.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:5
verses.text: By the trunk of this terebinth there was an altar on which the inhabitants of the country offered ectenae in their general assemblies; and though it seemed to be burned, it was not consumed.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:6
verses.text: Near it is the tomb of Abraham and Isaac.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 10:7
verses.text: And some say that the staff of one of the angels who were entertained by Abraham was planted there.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 11

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 11:1
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 11:2
verses.text: From Adam, therefore, to the death of Joseph, according to this book, are  generations, and  years.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 12

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 12:1
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 12:2
verses.text: From this record, therefore, we affirm that Ogygus, from whom the first flood (in Attica) derived its name, and who was saved when many perished, lived at the time of the exodus of the people from Egypt along with Moses.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 12:3
verses.text: (After a break): And after Ogygus, on account of the vast destruction caused by the flood, the present land of Attica remained without a king till the time of Cecrops,  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 12:4
verses.text: Philochorus, however, affirms that Ogygus, Actaeus, or whatever other fictitious name is adduced, never existed.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 12:5
verses.text: (After another break): From Ogygus to Cyrus, as from Moses to his time, are  years.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:1
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:2
verses.text: Up to the time of the Olympiads there is no certain history among the Greeks, all things before that date being confused, and in no way consistent with each other.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:3
verses.text: But these Olympiads were thoroughly investigated by many, as the Greeks made up the records of their history not according to long spaces, but in periods of four years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:4
verses.text: For which reason I shall select the most remarkable of the mythical narratives before the time of the first Olympiad, and rapidly run over them.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:5
verses.text: But those after that period, at least those that are notable, I shall take together, Hebrew events in connection with Greek, according to their dates, examining carefully the affairs of the Hebrews, and touching more cursorily on those of the Greeks; and my plan will be as follows: Taking up some single event in Hebrew history synchronous with another in Greek history, and keeping by it as the main subject, subtracting or adding as may seem needful in the narrative, I shall note what Greek or Persian of note, or remarkable personage of any other nationality, flourished at the date of that event in Hebrew history; and thus I may perhaps attain the object which I propose to myself.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:6
verses.text: The most famous exile that befell the Hebrews, then—to wit, when they were led captive by Nabuchodonosor king of Babylon—lasted  years, as Jeremias had prophesied.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:7
verses.text: Berosus the Babylonian, moreover, makes mention of Nabuchodonosor.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:8
verses.text: And after the  years of captivity, Cyrus became king of the Persians at the time of the th Olympiad, as may be ascertained from the Bibliothecae of Diodorus and the histories of Thallus and Castor, and also from Polybius and Phlegon, and others besides these, who have made the Olympiads a subject of study.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:9
verses.text: For the date is a matter of agreement among them all.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:10
verses.text: And Cyrus then, in the first year of his reign, which was the first year of the th Olympiad, effected the first partial restoration of the people by the hand of Zorobabel, with whom also was Jesus the son of Josedec, since the period of  years was now fulfilled, as is narrated in Esdra the Hebrew historian.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:11
verses.text: The narratives of the beginning of the sovereignty of Cyrus and the end of the captivity accordingly coincide.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:12
verses.text: And thus, according to the reckoning of the Olympiads, there will be found a like harmony of events even to our time.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:13
verses.text: And by following this, we shall also make the other narratives fit in with each other in the same manner.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:14
verses.text: But if the Attic time-reckoning is taken as the standard for affairs prior to these, then from Ogygus, who was believed by them to be an autochthon, in whose time also the first great flood took place in Attica, while Phoroneus reigned over the Argives, as Acusilaus relates, up to the date of the first Olympiad, from which period the Greeks thought they could fix dates accurately, there are altogether  years; which number both coincides with the above-mentioned, and will be established by what follows.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:15
verses.text: For these things are also recorded by the Athenian historians Hellanicus and Philochorus, who record Attic affairs; and by Castor and Thallus, who record Syrian affairs; and by Diodorus, who writes a universal history in his Bibliothecae; and by Alexander Polyhistor, and by some of our own time, yet more carefully, and by all the Attic writers.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:16
verses.text: Whatever narrative of note, therefore, meets us in these  years, shall be given in its proper place.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:17
verses.text: In accordance with this writing, therefore, we affirm that Ogygus, who gave his name to the first flood, and was saved when many perished, lived at the time of the exodus of the people from Egypt along with Moses.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:18
verses.text: And this we make out in the following manner.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:19
verses.text: From Ogygus up to the first Olympiad already mentioned, it will be shown that there are  years; and from the first Olympiad to the first year of the th, that is the first year of King Cyrus, which was also the end of the captivity, are  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:20
verses.text: From Ogygus, therefore, to Cyrus are.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:21
verses.text: And if one carries the calculation backwards from the end of the captivity, there are  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:22
verses.text: Thus, by analysis, the same period is found to the first year of the exodus of Israel under Moses from Egypt, as from the th Olympiad to Ogygus, who founded Eleusis.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:23
verses.text: And from this point we get a more notable beginning for Attic chronography.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:24
verses.text: So much, then, for the period prior to Ogygus.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:25
verses.text: And at his time Moses left Egypt.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:26
verses.text: And we demonstrate in the following manner how reliable is the statement that this happened at that date.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:27
verses.text: From the exodus of Moses up to Cyrus, who reigned after the captivity, are  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:28
verses.text: For the remaining years of Moses are.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:29
verses.text: The years of Jesus, who led the people after him, are ; those of the elders, who were judges after Jesus, are ; those of the judges, whose history is given in the book of Judges, are ; those of the priests Eli and Samuel are ; those of the successive kings of the Hebrews are.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:30
verses.text: Then come the  years of the captivity, the last year of which was the first year of the reign of Cyrus, as we have already said.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:31
verses.text: And from Moses, then, to the first Olympiad there are  years, as to the first year of the th Olympiad from the same are , in which enumeration the reckoning of the Greeks coincides with us.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:32
verses.text: And after Ogygus, by reason of the vast destruction caused by the flood, the present land of Attica remained without a king up to Cecrops, a period of  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:33
verses.text: For Philochorus asserts that the Actaeus who is said to have succeeded Ogygus, or whatever other fictitious names are adduced, never existed.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:34
verses.text: And again: From Ogygus, therefore, to Cyrus, says he, the same period is reckoned as from Moses to the same date, viz.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:35
verses.text: ,  years; and some of the Greeks also record that Moses lived at that same time.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:36
verses.text: Polemo, for instance, in the first book of his Greek History, says: In the time of Apis, son of Phoroneus, a division of the army of the Egyptians left Egypt, and settled in the Palestine called Syrian, not far from Arabia: these are evidently those who were with Moses.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:37
verses.text: And Apion the son of Poseidonius, the most laborious of grammarians, in his book Against the Jews, and in the fourth book of his History, says that in the time of Inachus king of Argos, when Amosis reigned over Egypt, the Jews revolted under the leadership of Moses.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:38
verses.text: And Herodotus also makes mention of this revolt, and of Amosis, in his second book, and in a certain way also of the Jews themselves, reckoning them among the circumcised, and calling them the Assyrians of Palestine, perhaps through Abraham.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:39
verses.text: And Ptolemy the Mendesian, who narrates the history of the Egyptians from the earliest times, gives the same account of all these things; so that among them in general there is no difference worth notice in the chronology.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:40
verses.text: It should be observed, further, that all the legendary accounts which are deemed specially remarkable by the Greeks by reason of their antiquity, are found to belong to a period posterior to Moses; such as their floods and conflagrations, Prometheus, Io, Europa, the Sparti, the abduction of Proserpine, their mysteries, their legislations, the deeds of Dionysus, Perseus, the Argonauts, the Centaurs, the Minotaur, the affairs of Troy, the labours of Hercules, the return of the Heraclidae, the Ionian migration and the Olympiads.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:41
verses.text: And it seemed good to me to give an account especially of the before-noted period of the Attic sovereignty, as I intend to narrate the history of the Greeks side by side with that of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:42
verses.text: For any one will be able, if he only start from my position, to make out the reckoning equally well with me.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:43
verses.text: Now, in the first year of that period of  years, stretching from Moses and Ogygus to the first Olympiad, the passover and the exodus of the Hebrews from Egypt took place, and also in Attica the flood of Ogygus.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:44
verses.text: And that is according to reason.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:45
verses.text: For when the Egyptians were being smitten in the anger of God with hail and storms, it was only to be expected that certain parts of the earth should suffer with them; and, in especial, it was but to be expected that the Athenians should participate in such calamity with the Egyptians, since they were supposed to be a colony from them, as Theopompus alleges in his Tricarenus, and others besides him.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:46
verses.text: The intervening period has been passed by, as no remarkable event is recorded during it among the Greeks.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 13:47
verses.text: But after  years Prometheus arose, according to some, who was fabulously reported to have formed men; for being a wise man, he transformed them from the state of extreme rudeness to culture.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 14

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 14:1
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 14:2
verses.text: aeschylus, the son of Agamestor, ruled the Athenians twenty-three years, in whose time Joatham reigned in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 14:3
verses.text: And our canon brings Joatham king of Juda within the first Olympiad.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 15

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 15:1
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 15:2
verses.text: And Africanus, in the third book of his History, writes: Now the first Olympiad recorded—which, however, was really the fourteenth—was the period when Coroebus was victor; at that time Ahaz was in the first year of his reign in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 15:3
verses.text: Then in the fourth book he says: It is therefore with the first year of the reign of Ahaz that we have shown the first Olympiad to fall in.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:1
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:2
verses.text: On the Seventy Weeks of Daniel.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:3
verses.text: This passage, therefore, as it stands thus, touches on many marvellous things.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:4
verses.text: At present, however, I shall speak only of those things in it which bear upon chronology, and matters connected therewith.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:5
verses.text: That the passage speaks then of the advent of Christ, who was to manifest Himself after seventy weeks, is evident.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:6
verses.text: For in the Saviour's time, or from Him, are transgressions abrogated, and sins brought to an end.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:7
verses.text: And through remission, moreover, are iniquities, along with offences, blotted out by expiation; and an everlasting righteousness is preached, different from that which is by the law, and visions and prophecies (are) until John, and the Most Holy is anointed.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:8
verses.text: For before the advent of the Saviour these things were not yet, and were therefore only looked for.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:9
verses.text: And the beginning of the numbers, that is, of the seventy weeks which make up  years, the angel instructs us to take from the going forth of the commandment to answer and to build Jerusalem.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:10
verses.text: And this happened in the twentieth year of the reign of Artaxerxes king of Persia.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:11
verses.text: For Nehemiah his cup-bearer besought him, and received the answer that Jerusalem should be built.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:12
verses.text: And the word went forth commanding these things; for up to that time the city was desolate.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:13
verses.text: For when Cyrus, after the seventy years' captivity, gave free permission to all to return who desired it, some of them under the leadership of Jesus the high priest and Zorobabel, and others after these under the leadership of Esdra, returned, but were prevented at first from building the temple, and from surrounding the city with a wall, on the plea that that had not been commanded.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:14
verses.text: It remained in this position, accordingly, until Nehemiah and the reign of Artaxerxes, and the th year of the sovereignty of the Persians.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:15
verses.text: And from the capture of Jerusalem that makes  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:16
verses.text: And at that time King Artaxerxes gave order that the city should be built; and Nehemiah being despatched, superintended the work, and the street and the surrounding wall were built, as had been prophesied.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:17
verses.text: And reckoning from that point, we make up seventy weeks to the time of Christ.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:18
verses.text: For if we begin to reckon from any other point, and not from this, the periods will not correspond, and very many odd results will meet us.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:19
verses.text: For if we begin the calculation of the seventy weeks from Cyrus and the first restoration, there will be upwards of one hundred years too many, and there will be a larger number if we begin from the day on which the angel gave the prophecy to Daniel, and a much larger number still if we begin from the commencement of the captivity.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:20
verses.text: For we find the sovereignty of the Persians comprising a period of  years, and that of the Macedonians extending over  years, and from that to the th year of Tiberius Caesar is a period of about  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:21
verses.text: It is by calculating from Artaxerxes, therefore, up to the time of Christ that the seventy weeks are made up, according to the numeration of the Jews.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:22
verses.text: For from Nehemiah, who was despatched by Artaxerxes to build Jerusalem in the th year of the Persian empire, and the th year of the d Olympiad, and the th year of the reign of Artaxerxes himself, up to this date, which was the second year of the d Olympiad, and the th year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, there are reckoned  years, which make  according to the Hebrew numeration, as they measure the years by the course of the moon; so that, as is easy to show, their year consists of  days, while the solar year has ¼ days.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:23
verses.text: For the latter exceeds the period of twelve months, according to the moon's course, by ¼ days.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:24
verses.text: Hence the Greeks and the Jews insert three intercalary months every  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:25
verses.text: For  times ¼ days makes up  months.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:26
verses.text: Therefore  years make  periods of  years each, and  months besides.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 16:27
verses.text: But since thus there are  intercalary months every  years, we get thus  years minus a few days; and these being added to the  years, make up in all the  weeks.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:1
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:2
verses.text: On the Fortunes of Hyrcanus and Antigonus, and on Herod, Augustus, Antony, and Cleopatra, in Abstract.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:3
verses.text: Octavius Sebastus, or, as the Romans call him, Augustus, the adopted son of Caius, on returning to Rome from Apollonias in Epirus, where he was educated, possessed himself of the first place in the government.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:4
verses.text: And Antony afterwards obtained the rule of Asia and the districts beyond.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:5
verses.text: In his time the Jews accused Herod; but he put the deputies to death, and restored Herod to his government.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:6
verses.text: Afterwards, however, along with Hyrcanus and Phasaelus his brother, he was driven out, and betook himself in flight to Antony.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:7
verses.text: And as the Jews would not receive him, an obstinate battle took place; and in a short time after, as he had conquered in battle, he also drove out Antigonus, who had returned.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:8
verses.text: And Antigonus fled to Herod the Parthian king, and was restored by the help of his son Pacorus, which help was given on his promising to pay  talents of gold.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:9
verses.text: And Herod then in his turn had to flee, while Phasaelus was slain in battle, and Hyrcanus was surrendered alive to Antigonus.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:10
verses.text: And after cutting off his ears, that he might be disqualified for the priesthood, he gave him to the Parthians to lead into captivity; for he scrupled to put him to death, as he was a relation of his own.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:11
verses.text: And Herod, on his expulsion, betook himself first to Malichus king of the Arabians; and when he did not receive him, through fear of the Parthians, he went away to Alexandria to Cleopatra.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:12
verses.text: That was the th Olympiad.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:13
verses.text: Cleopatra having put to death her brother, who was her consort in the government, and being then summoned by Antony to Cilicia to make her defence, committed the care of the sovereignty to Herod; and as he requested that he should not be entrusted with anything until he was restored to his own government, she took him with her and went to Antony.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:14
verses.text: And as he was smitten with love for the princess, they despatched Herod to Rome to Octavius Augustus, who, on behalf of Antipater, Herod's father, and on behalf of Herod himself, and also because Antigonus was established as king by the help of the Parthians, gave a commission to the generals in Palestine and Syria to restore him to his government.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:15
verses.text: And in concert with Sosius he waged war against Antigonus for a long time, and in manifold engagements.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:16
verses.text: At that time also, Josephus, Herod's brother, died in his command.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:17
verses.text: And Herod coming to Antony ….

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:18
verses.text: For three years they besieged Antigonus, and then brought him alive to Antony.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:19
verses.text: And Antony himself also proclaimed Herod as king, and gave him, in addition, the cities Hippus, Gadara, Gaza, Joppa, Anthedon, and a part of Arabia, Trachonitis, and Auranitis, and Sacia, and Gaulanitis; and besides these, also the procuratorship of Syria.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:20
verses.text: Herod was declared king of the Jews by the senate and Octavius Augustus, and reigned  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:21
verses.text: Antony, when about to go on an expedition against the Parthians, slew Antigonus the king of the Jews, and gave Arabia to Cleopatra; and passing over into the territory of the Parthians, sustained a severe defeat, losing the greater part of his army.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:22
verses.text: That was in the th Olympiad.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:23
verses.text: Octavius Augustus led the forces of Italy and all the West against Antony, who refused to return to Rome through fear, on account of his failure in Parthia, and through his love for Cleopatra.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:24
verses.text: And Antony met him with the forces of Asia.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:25
verses.text: Herod, however, like a shrewd fellow, and one who waits upon the powerful, sent a double set of letters, and despatched his army to sea, charging his generals to watch the issue of events.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:26
verses.text: And when the victory was decided, and when Antony, after sustaining two naval defeats, had fled to Egypt along with Cleopatra, they who bore the letters delivered to Augustus those which they had been keeping secretly for Antony.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:27
verses.text: And on Herod falls….

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:28
verses.text: Cleopatra shut herself up in a mausoleum, and made away with herself, employing the wild asp as the instrument of death.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:29
verses.text: At that time Augustus captured Cleopatra's sons, Helios and Selene, on their flight to the Thebaid.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:30
verses.text: Nicopolis was founded opposite Actium, and the games called Actia were instituted.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:31
verses.text: On the capture of Alexandria, Cornelius Gallus was sent as first governor of Egypt, and he destroyed the cities of the Egyptians that refused obedience.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:32
verses.text: Up to this time the Lagidae ruled; and the whole duration of the Macedonian empire after the subversion of the Persian power was  years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:33
verses.text: Thus is made up the whole period from the foundation of the Macedonian empire to its subversion in the time of the Ptolemies, and under Cleopatra, the last of these, the date of which event is the th year of the monarchy and empire of the Romans, and the th year of the th Olympiad.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:34
verses.text: Altogether, from Adam  years are reckoned.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:35
verses.text: After the taking of Alexandria the th Olympiad began.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:36
verses.text: Herod founded anew the city of the Gabinii, the ancient Samaria, and called it Sebaste; and having erected its seaport, the tower of Strato, into a city, he named it Caesarea after the same, and raised in each a temple in honour of Octavius.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:37
verses.text: And afterwards he founded Antipatris in the Lydian plain, so naming it after his father, and settled in it the people about Sebaste, whom he had dispossessed of their land.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:38
verses.text: He founded also other cities; and to the Jews he was severe, but to other nations most urbane.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 17:39
verses.text: It was now the th Olympiad, which (Olympiad) in the year that had the bissextile day, the th day before the Calends of March,—i-e:, the th of February,—corresponded with the th year of the era of Antioch, whereby the year was determined in its proper limits.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:1
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:2
verses.text: On the Circumstances Connected with Our Saviour's Passion and His Life-Giving Resurrection.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:3
verses.text: As to His works severally, and His cures effected upon body and soul, and the mysteries of His doctrine, and the resurrection from the dead, these have been most authoritatively set forth by His disciples and apostles before us.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:4
verses.text: On the whole world there pressed a most fearful darkness; and the rocks were rent by an earthquake, and many places in Judea and other districts were thrown down.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:5
verses.text: This darkness Thallus, in the third book of his History, calls, as appears to me without reason, an eclipse of the sun.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:6
verses.text: For the Hebrews celebrate the passover on the th day according to the moon, and the passion of our Saviour falls on the day before the passover; but an eclipse of the sun takes place only when the moon comes under the sun.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:7
verses.text: And it cannot happen at any other time but in the interval between the first day of the new moon and the last of the old, that is, at their junction: how then should an eclipse be supposed to happen when the moon is almost diametrically opposite the sun? Let that opinion pass however; let it carry the majority with it; and let this portent of the world be deemed an eclipse of the sun, like others a portent only to the eye.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:8
verses.text: Phlegon records that, in the time of Tiberius Caesar, at full moon, there was a full eclipse of the sun from the sixth hour to the ninth—manifestly that one of which we speak.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:9
verses.text: But what has an eclipse in common with an earthquake, the rending rocks, and the resurrection of the dead, and so great a perturbation throughout the universe? Surely no such event as this is recorded for a long period.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:10
verses.text: But it was a darkness induced by God, because the Lord happened then to suffer.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:11
verses.text: And calculation makes out that the period of  weeks, as noted in Daniel, is completed at this time.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:12
verses.text: From Artaxerxes, moreover,  weeks are reckoned up to the time of Christ, according to the numeration of the Jews.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:13
verses.text: For from Nehemiah, who was sent by Artaxerxes to people Jerusalem, about the th year of the Persian empire, and in the th year of Artaxerxes himself, and the th year of the d Olympiad, up to this time, which was the d year of the d Olympiad, and the th year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, there are given  years, which make  Hebrew years, since they measure the years by the lunar month of ½ days, as may easily be explained, the annual period according to the sun consisting of ¼ days, while the lunar period of  months has ¼ days less.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:14
verses.text: For which reason the Greeks and the Jews insert three intercalary months every eight years.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:15
verses.text: For  times ¼ days make  months.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:16
verses.text: The  years, therefore, contain  periods of  years and three months over: thus, the three intercalary months for every  years being added, we get  years, and these together with the  years make  weeks.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:17
verses.text: Let no one now think us unskilled in the calculations of astronomy, when we fix without further ado the number of days at ¼.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:18
verses.text: For it is not in ignorance of the truth, but rather by reason of exact study, that we have stated our opinion so shortly.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:19
verses.text: But let what follows also be presented as in outline to those who endeavour to inquire minutely into all things.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:20
verses.text: Each year in the general consists of  days; and the space of a day and night being divided into nineteen parts, we have also five of these.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:21
verses.text: And in saying that the year consists of ¼ days, and there being the five nineteenth parts…to the  there are ¼ days.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:22
verses.text: Furthermore, we find, according to exact computation, that the lunar month has ½ days.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:23
verses.text: … And these come to a little time.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:24
verses.text: Now it happens that from the th year of the reign of Artaxerxes (as it is given in Ezra among the Hebrews), which, according to the Greeks, was the th year of the th Olympiad, to the th year of Tiberius Caesar, which was the second year of the d Olympiad, there are in all the  years already noted, which in the Hebrew system make  years, as has been previously stated, that is,  weeks, by which period the time of Christ's advent was measured in the announcement made to Daniel by Gabriel.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:25
verses.text: And if any one thinks that the  Hebrew years added to the others involve us in an error of , nothing at least which cannot be accounted for has been introduced.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:26
verses.text: And the ½ week which we suppose must be added to make the whole number, meets the question about the  years, and removes the difficulty about the time; and that the prophecies are usually put forth in a somewhat symbolic form, is quite evident.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:27
verses.text: As far, then, as is in our power, we have taken the Scripture, I think, correctly; especially seeing that the preceding section about the vision seems to state the whole matter shortly, its first words being, "In the third year of the reign of Belshazzar," where he prophesies of the subversion of the Persian power by the Greeks, which empires are symbolized in the prophecy under the figures of the ram and the goat respectively.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:28
verses.text: "The sacrifice," he says, "shall be abolished, and the holy places shall be made desolate, so as to be trodden under foot; which things shall be determined within  days".

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:29
verses.text: For if we take the day as a month, just as elsewhere in prophecy days are taken as years, and in different places are used in different ways, reducing the period in the same way as has been done above to Hebrew months, we shall find the period fully made out to the th year of the reign of Artaxerxes, from the capture of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:30
verses.text: For there are given thus  years, and one year falls to be added to these—the year in which Nehemiah built the wall of the city.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:31
verses.text: In  years, therefore, we find  Hebrew months, as  years have in addition  intercalary months.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:32
verses.text: From Artaxerxes, again, in whose time the command went forth that Jerusalem should be built, there are  weeks.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:33
verses.text: These matters, however, we have discussed by themselves, and with greater exactness, in our book On the Weeks and this Prophecy.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:34
verses.text: But I am amazed that the Jews deny that the Lord has yet come, and that the followers of Marcion refuse to admit that His coming was predicted in the prophecies when the Scriptures display the matter so openly to our view.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 18:35
verses.text: And after something else: The period, then, to the advent of the Lord from Adam and the creation is  years, from which epoch to the th Olympiad there are  years, as has been shown above.

chapters.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 19

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 19:1
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Julius Africanus: On the Mythical Chronology of the Egyptians and Chaldeans 19:2
verses.text: For we who both know the measure of those words, and are not ignorant of the grace of faith, give thanks to the Father, who has bestowed on us His creatures Jesus Christ the Saviour of all, and our Lord; to whom be glory and majesty, with the Holy Spirit, for ever.
